statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
Boston Celtics came back home and found their
winning touch from an unlikely source.
article.headline: Anderson gets loose for season-high 19 points

images.name: Anderson, Kenny 020102 inline
images.caption: Boston's Kenny Anderson finds a lane between Orlando's Pat Garrity, left, and  Patrick Ewing on his way to a season-high 19 points.

article.linkText: Anderson chips in as Celtics continue hot home streak
article.story:
BOSTON (AP) -- The Boston Celtics came back home and found their winning touch from an unlikely source. Kenny Anderson scored all of his season-high 19 points in the first half Wednesday night as the Boston Celtics beat the Orlando Magic 110-94 and won their seventh consecutive home game. "It's 2002. (I've got to) get back to being Kenny," said Anderson, who added seven assists, five rebounds and four steals for his best game since scoring 20 on Dec. 28, 2000. "(I) got back to being aggressive." Antoine Walker scored 30 with nine assists, Paul Pierce had 24 points and eight rebounds and Vitaly Potapenko had 10 points and nine rebounds for the Celtics, who returned home after a 1-3 road trip bounced them from the Eastern Conference lead. "They beat ... us in every way possible. That's just the way it goes sometimes," Magic coach Doc Rivers said. "Pierce and Walker hurt us, but Kenny Anderson killed us." Pat Garrity scored 19 for the Magic, and Tracy McGrady and Mike Miller each had 15 for Orlando, which had won two consecutive. Darrell Armstrong had 13 assists and six rebounds, but he also had eight turnovers and only three points as Orlando fell behind in the second quarter and never threatened thereafter. The Celtics, who haven't made the playoffs since 1995, won 12 of 14 games before Christmas to take over first place in the Eastern Conference. But they lost three out of four on their West Coast road trip. "We've played better at home and we've also played better on the road," Celtics coach Jim O'Brien said. "To be .500 (8-8) on the road is solid. If you play .500 on the road for the year, there's a good chance you'll have home court advantage for the playoffs." Back at home, the Celtics held a 32-30 lead early in the second quarter before mounting a 18-6 run capped by Anderson's layup that made it 50-36 with 5:43 to play in the half. "That's a different Boston Celtics team," Rivers said. "They've been struggling over the last couple years, but now they're playing terrific ball." Game notes
Pierce and Walker were the NBA's co-players of the month for December. "That's appropriate. It's good to see that. They're joined at the hip," O'Brien said. Either Walker or Pierce has led Boston in scoring for 101 of the last 102 games. Walter McCarty led the team in scoring last April 15. ... Orlando had been 13-5 when leading after the first quarter. ... Pierce (27.3) and McGrady (26.1) came into the game second and third in the league in scoring.
